pullRequest.title: Grizzly-http and grizzly-client instrumentation
pullRequest.bodyText:
The Mulesoft instrumentation traces API calls made from HttpListener and HttpRequester components. Under the hood, these components use grizzly for both the server and client logic. As a result, this PR adds instrumentation to Grizzly.
For development purposes, the instrumentation is currently located in the mule-http-connector module of the tracer. However, it should be added to the grizzly module before being merged.

nodes.bodyText: Executor instrumentation was skipped for these four executors. FixedThreadPool, specifically, is instantiated by GrizzlyExecutorService after HttpServerFilter receives a request. QueueLimitedThreadPool is created if a FixedThreadPool cannot be created. Fixed, QueueLimited, and Sync all extend AbstractThreadPool. Would it make more sense to just add AbstractThreadPool to the whitelist?
nodes.diffHunk:

         "kotlinx.coroutines.scheduling.CoroutineScheduler",
         "org.eclipse.jetty.util.thread.QueuedThreadPool",
         "org.eclipse.jetty.util.thread.ReservedThreadExecutor",
+        "org.glassfish.grizzly.threadpool.AbstractThreadPool",
+        "org.glassfish.grizzly.threadpool.FixedThreadPool",
         "org.glassfish.grizzly.threadpool.GrizzlyExecutorService",
+        "org.glassfish.grizzly.threadpool.QueueLimitedThreadPool",
+        "org.glassfish.grizzly.threadpool.SyncThreadPool",

nodes.bodyText: Does the span need to be activated here? Should a scope be created considering it will be closed at the end of the function.
This is in-line with the comment in ClientRequestAdvice. Should the span be reactivated here?
Classes in the "clientV2" package can be ignored during review. Please review the classes in the "client" package instead. I was experimenting with slightly different instrumentation for the client.

nodes.bodyText: When a request is made to the server that then triggers a network request from the client, two traces are created instead of a single trace with the server span as the parent and the client span as the child. I have set asyncPropagation to true, but I have also closed the scope. Would that result in the disconnected server and client spans?

This needs to be updated to call the connector method. It should also set SUCCESS.body to the body of the response instead of the reasonPhrase. However, it is unclear how to do this. It may be possible to write the response body using ctx.write().

afterCommit.message: change component name of client instrumentation to include grizzly

nodes.bodyText: The span is activated and the scope is explicitly closed. However, the logs point to an error where the tracer is attempting to close a specific scope while the current scope is "null". This code may be the cause for that error.

nodes.bodyText: Since this instrumentation all belongs to grizzly, let's move this to the grizzly-2 folder.  The only mule reference should be in muzzle (which we decided we couldn't do), or a test, but I don't think we have any tests actually exercising mule, only grizzly.

nodes.bodyText: See also: HttpServerDecorator.DD_SPAN_ATTRIBUTE
Please add a comment that the scope is closed in ClientResponseAdvice

For fun can you add a test dependency on netty-3.8 and see if that has any impact when you run the client test?  Netty38ClientTest uses "ning" async-http-client which might already cover what we are doing here. (unless grizzly is using the same framework but swapping out the networking layer somehow, which would be interesting...)

@@ -0,0 +1,30 @@
+// no muzzle until/unless muzzle supports maven classifiers
+
+apply from: "${rootDir}/gradle/java.gradle"
+
+apply plugin: 'org.unbroken-dome.test-sets'
+
+repositories {
+  jcenter()
+  maven {
+    url "https://repository.mulesoft.org/releases/"
+  }
+}
+
+dependencies {
+
+  compileOnly group: 'org.mule.connectors', name: 'mule-http-connector', version: '1.5.14', classifier: 'mule-plugin'
+  compileOnly group: 'org.mule.runtime', name: 'mule-service-http-api', version: '4.1.1'
+  compileOnly group: 'org.mule.services', name: 'mule-service-http', version: '1.1.1'
+  compileOnly group: 'org.glassfish.grizzly', name: 'grizzly-http', version: '2.3.35'
+  compileOnly group: 'org.glassfish.grizzly', name: 'grizzly-http-client', version: '1.14'
+
+  testCompile group: 'org.glassfish.grizzly', name: 'grizzly-http-client', version: '1.14'
+  testCompile group: 'org.glassfish.grizzly', name: 'grizzly-http-server', version: '2.0'
+  testCompile project(':dd-java-agent:instrumentation:java-concurrent')

nodes.bodyText: Why is this labeled as supporting only 1.9 but the project name suggests 1.1?  If 1.9 is the minimum supported version, you should rename the project to match.
let's have this set to "ning", "grizzly-client"
This should match the changes suggested for the decorator.
Please add an additional pass block asserting the ning dependency.
Did you want a static import here
This should probably be minimum version from the muzzle check
We tend to do a null check on these but I don't think it could be null here
We might want a follow-up PR that goes through all the others and moves them here
Instead of casting, could you use AsyncHandler as the type on InstrumentationContext?
It's easy to lose track of what's left and what's right below... consider assigning them to more descriptive local variables early.

I would suggest having this instrumentation use "grizzly-filterchain" and the old grizzly instrumentation use "grizzly", "grizzly-httphandler" as instrumentation names.  That way they can be configured independently.  Ideally this would also use grizzly but if someone already enabled the old one, this would potentially be enabled too.
For now, can we have these new integrations disabled by default (see how it's done in the grizzly instrumentation)?
(You'll also need to add the system property to enable it in the tests.)
This needs to match.
Please alphabetize.
